title: Camila Cabello 'in tears' after watching Jesy Nelson's Odd One Out
text:
Jesy Nelson left Camila Cabello in ‘tears’ (Picture: BBC/Getty)

Camila Cabello has revealed how she ‘teared up’ watching Jesy Nelson’s emotional BBC documentary Odd One Out.

The former Fifth Harmony star turned solo singer has previously spoken about her own struggles with social media, and how she refuses to use Twitter and only occasionally Instagram due to the pressure it puts on her.

But now she has admitted that Jesy’s documentary ‘made such a big impression’ and that she felt Jesy’s ‘pain’.

‘Not to that point but I definitely felt the depths of struggling, and when I heard that, I just really felt what she was saying,’ she said.

‘I felt her pain, and for somebody to rise out of that place takes so much strength.’

Speaking to The Sun, she added: ‘I don’t go on Twitter at all. Twitter is f***ing terrible. I’m mostly on Instagram because I want to interact with my fans. But I just felt an hour ago, “Eurgh, I wanna delete this app”.

‘You get sucked back into it again and it takes you away from real life. That’s the least of the worst scenarios.’

Camila Cabello was moved to tears by Jesy’s documentary (Picture: Getty)

The Little Mix singer broke records for the BBC with her courageous documentary attacking online trolls and bullying, titled Odd One Out.

Jesy revealed in the film that she once tried to take her own life in 2013 after being barraged with vicious social media users abusing her every day since winning The X Factor in 2011.

Odd One Out initially aired to huge acclaim on BBC One earlier this month before moving to BBC Three where it was watched by more than 3.3 million viewers, the highest figures for the channel since it moved online.

The 28-year-old’s special saw 1.87 million requests to view over the course of a week, with 64 percent of those coming from 16-34-year-olds.

Odd One Out saw Jesy collapse into tears after recalling her own suicide attempt and revealing the extent of the abuse she received online which tarnished winning The X Factor – what should have been the best day of her life.

‘I just remember thinking this is never going to go,’ she sobbed.

‘I’m going to constantly wake up and feel sad for the rest of my life. So what is the point in being here? I physically couldn’t tolerate the pain any more.’
